mn114:0.2.eng: What Should and Should Not Be Cultivated

mn114:1.1.comm: The Buddha begins by speaking of what should and should not be cultivated. Then he goes on to offer three distinct analyses of this, each laid out in a series of dichotomies. After each one, Sāriputta offers a lengthy elaboration, which the Buddha then approves and recapitulates.

mn114:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn114:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn114:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn114:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you an exposition of the teaching on what should and should not be cultivated.
mn114:2.1.comm: To “cultivate” is to foster or nurture through repeated association or practice.

mn114:2.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn114:2.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn114:2.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

mn114:3.1.eng: “I say that there are two kinds of bodily behavior:
mn114:3.1.comm: The first analysis consists of seven items: bodily, verbal, and mental conduct; arising of thought; and acquisition of perception, views, and reincarnation.

mn114:3.2.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:3.3.eng: And each of these is a kind of bodily behavior.

mn114:3.4.eng: I say that there are two kinds of verbal behavior:

mn114:3.5.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:3.6.eng: And each of these is a kind of verbal behavior.

mn114:3.7.eng: I say that there are two kinds of mental behavior:

mn114:3.8.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:3.9.eng: And each of these is a kind of mental behavior.

mn114:3.10.eng: I say that there are two arisings of thought:

mn114:3.11.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:3.12.eng: And each of these is an arising of thought.

mn114:3.13.eng: I say that there are two acquisitions of perception:

mn114:3.14.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:3.15.eng: And each of these is an acquisition of perception.

mn114:3.16.eng: I say that there are two acquisitions of views:

mn114:3.17.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:3.18.eng: And each of these is an acquisition of views.

mn114:3.19.eng: I say that there are two kinds of incarnation:
mn114:3.19.comm: “Life-form” is attabhāva, literally the “state of the self”, where the “self” comes close in meaning to “body”—whether material or immaterial—which is a secondary sense of ātman in the Upaniṣads. Accordingly, the commentary to AN 5.100 glosses as sarīrapaṭilābha. | “Reincarnation” is paṭilābha. In the 20th century, Buddhist writers shied away from using “reincarnation”, which they associated with the Hindu idea of a transmigrating soul. But there is nothing in the word “reincarnation” that implies a soul. Rather, it simply refers to going into another body, which is precisely what is meant by attabhāva. It is unwise to hang a heavy philosophical cloak upon the feeble hook of a single word.

mn114:3.20.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn114:4.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Sāriputta said to the Buddha,
mn114:4.1.comm: Sāriputta proceeds to elaborate each of the seven items in turn.

mn114:4.2.pli: “imassa kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa, vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa, evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi.
mn114:4.2.eng: “Sir, this is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.

mn114:5.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of bodily behavior:

mn114:5.2.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:5.3.eng: And each of these is a kind of bodily behavior.’

mn114:5.5.eng: but why did he say it?

mn114:5.6.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, bhante, kāyasamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, evarūpo kāyasamācāro na sevitabbo;
mn114:5.6.eng: You should not cultivate the kind of bodily behavior which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:5.7.pli: yathārūpañca kho, bhante, kāyasamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, evarūpo kāyasamācāro sevitabbo.
mn114:5.7.eng: And you should cultivate the kind of bodily behavior which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:5.8.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, bhante, kāyasamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti?
mn114:5.8.eng: And what kind of bodily behavior causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline?
mn114:5.8.comm: This includes the first three precepts, or else the first three of the ten ways of skillful deeds.

mn114:5.9.pli: Idha, bhante, ekacco pāṇātipātī hoti luddo lohitapāṇi hatappahate niviṭṭho adayāpanno pāṇabhūtesu;
mn114:5.9.eng: It’s when someone kills living creatures. They’re violent, bloody-handed, a hardened killer, merciless to living beings.

mn114:5.10.pli: adinnādāyī kho pana hoti, yaṃ taṃ parassa paravittūpakaraṇaṃ gāmagataṃ vā araññagataṃ vā taṃ adinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādātā hoti;
mn114:5.10.eng: They steal. With the intention to commit theft, they take the wealth or belongings of others from village or wilderness.

mn114:5.11.pli: kāmesumicchācārī kho pana hoti, yā tā māturakkhitā piturakkhitā mātāpiturakkhitā bhāturakkhitā bhaginirakkhitā ñātirakkhitā gottarakkhitā dhammarakkhitā sassāmikā saparidaṇḍā antamaso mālāguḷaparikkhittāpi tathārūpāsu cārittaṃ āpajjitā hoti—
mn114:5.11.eng: They commit sexual misconduct. They have sexual relations with women who have their mother, father, both mother and father, brother, sister, relatives, or clan as guardian. They have sexual relations with a woman who is protected on principle, or who has a husband, or whose violation is punishable by law, or even one who has been garlanded as a token of betrothal.

mn114:5.12.pli: evarūpaṃ, bhante, kāyasamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti.
mn114:5.12.eng: That kind of bodily behavior causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:5.13.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, bhante, kāyasamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti?
mn114:5.13.eng: And what kind of bodily behavior causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow?

mn114:5.14.pli: Idha, bhante, ekacco pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho, lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati;
mn114:5.14.eng: It’s when someone gives up killing living creatures. They renounce the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.

mn114:5.15.pli: adinnādānaṃ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, yaṃ taṃ parassa paravittūpakaraṇaṃ gāmagataṃ vā araññagataṃ vā taṃ nādinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādātā hoti;
mn114:5.15.eng: They give up stealing. They don’t, with the intention to commit theft, take the wealth or belongings of others from village or wilderness.

mn114:5.16.pli: kāmesumicchācāraṃ pahāya kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, yā tā māturakkhitā piturakkhitā mātāpiturakkhitā bhāturakkhitā bhaginirakkhitā ñātirakkhitā gottarakkhitā dhammarakkhitā sassāmikā saparidaṇḍā antamaso mālāguḷaparikkhittāpi tathārūpāsu na cārittaṃ āpajjitā hoti—
mn114:5.16.eng: They give up sexual misconduct. They don’t have sexual relations with women who have their mother, father, both mother and father, brother, sister, relatives, or clan as guardian. They don’t have sexual relations with a woman who is protected on principle, or who has a husband, or whose violation is punishable by law, or even one who has been garlanded as a token of betrothal.

mn114:5.17.pli: evarūpaṃ, bhante, kāyasamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn114:5.17.eng: That kind of bodily behavior causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:5.18.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of bodily behavior:

mn114:5.19.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:5.20.eng: And each of these is a kind of bodily behavior.’

mn114:5.21.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn114:5.21.eng: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.

mn114:6.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of verbal behavior:

mn114:6.2.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:6.3.eng: And each of these is a kind of verbal behavior.’

mn114:6.5.eng: but why did he say it?

mn114:6.6.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, bhante, vacīsamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, evarūpo vacīsamācāro na sevitabbo;
mn114:6.6.eng: You should not cultivate the kind of verbal behavior which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:6.7.pli: yathārūpañca kho, bhante, vacīsamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti evarūpo vacīsamācāro sevitabbo.
mn114:6.7.eng: And you should cultivate the kind of verbal behavior which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:6.8.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, bhante, vacīsamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti?
mn114:6.8.eng: And what kind of verbal behavior causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline?
mn114:6.8.comm: This is the four verbal ways of skillful deeds.

mn114:6.9.pli: Idha, bhante, ekacco musāvādī hoti. Sabhāgato vā parisāgato vā ñātimajjhagato vā pūgamajjhagato vā rājakulamajjhagato vā abhinīto sakkhipuṭṭho: ‘ehambho purisa, yaṃ jānāsi taṃ vadehī’ti so ajānaṃ vā āha: ‘jānāmī’ti, jānaṃ vā āha: ‘na jānāmī’ti; apassaṃ vā āha: ‘passāmī’ti, passaṃ vā āha: ‘na passāmī’ti—iti attahetu vā parahetu vā āmisakiñcikkhahetu vā sampajānamusā bhāsitā hoti;
mn114:6.9.eng: It’s when someone lies. They’re summoned to a council, an assembly, a family meeting, a guild, or to the royal court, and asked to bear witness: ‘Please, worthy man, say what you know.’ Not knowing, they say ‘I know.’ Knowing, they say ‘I don’t know.’ Not seeing, they say ‘I see.’ And seeing, they say ‘I don’t see.’ So they deliberately lie for the sake of themselves or another, or for some trivial worldly reason.

mn114:6.10.pli: pisuṇavāco kho pana hoti, ito sutvā amutra akkhātā imesaṃ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā imesaṃ akkhātā amūsaṃ bhedāya—iti samaggānaṃ vā bhettā, bhinnānaṃ vā anuppadātā, vaggārāmo, vaggarato, vagganandī, vaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti;
mn114:6.10.eng: They speak divisively. They repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. And so they divide those who are harmonious, supporting division, delighting in division, loving division, speaking words that promote division.

mn114:6.11.pli: pharusavāco kho pana hoti, yā sā vācā kaṇḍakā kakkasā pharusā parakaṭukā parābhisajjanī kodhasāmantā asamādhisaṃvattanikā, tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti;
mn114:6.11.eng: They speak harshly. They use the kinds of words that are cruel, nasty, hurtful, offensive, bordering on anger, not leading to immersion.

mn114:6.12.pli: samphappalāpī kho pana hoti akālavādī abhūtavādī anatthavādī adhammavādī avinayavādī, anidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti akālena anapadesaṃ apariyantavatiṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ—
mn114:6.12.eng: They talk nonsense. Their speech is untimely, and is neither factual nor beneficial. It has nothing to do with the teaching or the training. Their words have no value, and are untimely, unreasonable, rambling, and pointless.

mn114:6.13.pli: evarūpaṃ, bhante, vacīsamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti.
mn114:6.13.eng: That kind of verbal behavior causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:6.14.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, bhante, vacīsamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti?
mn114:6.14.eng: And what kind of verbal behavior causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow?

mn114:6.15.pli: Idha, bhante, ekacco musāvādaṃ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti sabhāgato vā parisāgato vā ñātimajjhagato vā pūgamajjhagato vā rājakulamajjhagato vā abhinīto sakkhipuṭṭho: ‘ehambho purisa, yaṃ jānāsi taṃ vadehī’ti so ajānaṃ vā āha: ‘na jānāmī’ti, jānaṃ vā āha: ‘jānāmī’ti, apassaṃ vā āha: ‘na passāmī’ti, passaṃ vā āha: ‘passāmī’ti—iti attahetu vā parahetu vā āmisakiñcikkhahetu vā na sampajānamusā bhāsitā hoti;
mn114:6.15.eng: It’s when a certain person gives up lying. They’re summoned to a council, an assembly, a family meeting, a guild, or to the royal court, and asked to bear witness: ‘Please, worthy man, say what you know.’ Not knowing, they say ‘I don’t know.’ Knowing, they say ‘I know.’ Not seeing, they say ‘I don’t see.’ And seeing, they say ‘I see.’ So they don’t deliberately lie for the sake of themselves or another, or for some trivial worldly reason.

mn114:6.16.pli: pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṃ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṃ akkhātā amūsaṃ bhedāya—iti bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātā sahitānaṃ vā anuppadātā samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti;
mn114:6.16.eng: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.

mn114:6.17.pli: pharusaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti;
mn114:6.17.eng: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.

mn114:6.18.pli: samphappalāpaṃ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti kālena sāpadesaṃ pariyantavatiṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ—
mn114:6.18.eng: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.

mn114:6.19.pli: evarūpaṃ, bhante, vacīsamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn114:6.19.eng: That kind of verbal behavior causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:6.20.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of verbal behavior:

mn114:6.21.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:6.22.eng: And each of these is a kind of verbal behavior.’

mn114:6.23.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn114:6.23.eng: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.

mn114:7.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of mental behavior:

mn114:7.2.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:7.3.eng: And each of these is a kind of mental behavior.’

mn114:7.5.eng: but why did he say it?

mn114:7.6.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, bhante, manosamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti evarūpo manosamācāro na sevitabbo;
mn114:7.6.eng: You should not cultivate the kind of mental behavior which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:7.7.pli: yathārūpañca kho, bhante, manosamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti evarūpo manosamācāro sevitabbo.
mn114:7.7.eng: And you should cultivate the kind of mental behavior which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:7.8.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, bhante, manosamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti?
mn114:7.8.eng: And what kind of mental behavior causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline?
mn114:7.8.comm: This is the final three ways of skillful deeds.

mn114:7.9.pli: Idha, bhante, ekacco abhijjhālu hoti, yaṃ taṃ parassa paravittūpakaraṇaṃ taṃ abhijjhātā hoti: ‘aho vata yaṃ parassa taṃ mamassā’ti;
mn114:7.9.eng: It’s when someone is covetous. They covet the wealth and belongings of others: ‘Oh, if only their belongings were mine!’

mn114:7.10.pli: byāpannacitto kho pana hoti paduṭṭhamanasaṅkappo: ‘ime sattā haññantu vā vajjhantu vā ucchijjantu vā vinassantu vā mā vā ahesun’ti—
mn114:7.10.eng: They have ill will and malicious intentions: ‘May these sentient beings be killed, slaughtered, slain, destroyed, or annihilated!’

mn114:7.11.pli: evarūpaṃ, bhante, manosamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti.
mn114:7.11.eng: That kind of mental behavior causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:7.12.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, bhante, manosamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti?
mn114:7.12.eng: And what kind of mental behavior causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow?

mn114:7.13.pli: Idha, bhante, ekacco anabhijjhālu hoti, yaṃ taṃ parassa paravittūpakaraṇaṃ taṃ nābhijjhātā hoti: ‘aho vata yaṃ parassa taṃ mamassā’ti;
mn114:7.13.eng: It’s when someone is content. They don’t covet the wealth and belongings of others: ‘Oh, if only their belongings were mine!’

mn114:7.14.pli: abyāpannacitto kho pana hoti appaduṭṭhamanasaṅkappo: ‘ime sattā averā abyābajjhā anīghā sukhī attānaṃ pariharantū’ti—
mn114:7.14.eng: They have a kind heart and loving intentions: ‘May these sentient beings live free of enmity and ill will, untroubled and happy!’

mn114:7.15.pli: evarūpaṃ, bhante, manosamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn114:7.15.eng: That kind of mental behavior causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:7.16.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of mental behavior:

mn114:7.17.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:7.18.eng: And each of these is a kind of mental behavior.’

mn114:7.19.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn114:7.19.eng: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.

mn114:8.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two arisings of thought:

mn114:8.2.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:8.3.eng: And each of these is an arising of thought.’

mn114:8.5.eng: but why did he say it?

mn114:8.6.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, bhante, cittuppādaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti evarūpo cittuppādo na sevitabbo;
mn114:8.6.eng: You should not cultivate the arising of thought which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:8.7.pli: yathārūpañca kho, bhante, cittuppādaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti evarūpo cittuppādo sevitabbo.
mn114:8.7.eng: And you should cultivate the arising of thought which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:8.8.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, bhante, cittuppādaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti?
mn114:8.8.eng: And what arising of thought causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline?
mn114:8.8.comm: The discussions at MN 8:13.1 and AN 7.53 show that this refers to the initial thought that precedes action.

mn114:8.9.pli: Idha, bhante, ekacco abhijjhālu hoti, abhijjhāsahagatena cetasā viharati;
mn114:8.9.eng: It’s when someone is covetous, and lives with their heart full of covetousness.

mn114:8.10.eng: They are malicious, and live with their heart full of ill will.

mn114:8.11.eng: They’re hurtful, and live with their heart intent on harm.

mn114:8.12.pli: evarūpaṃ, bhante, cittuppādaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti.
mn114:8.12.eng: That arising of thought causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:8.13.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, bhante, cittuppādaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti?
mn114:8.13.eng: And what arising of thought causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow?

mn114:8.14.pli: Idha, bhante, ekacco anabhijjhālu hoti, anabhijjhāsahagatena cetasā viharati;
mn114:8.14.eng: It’s when someone is content, and lives with their heart full of contentment.

mn114:8.15.eng: They have good will, and live with their heart full of good will.

mn114:8.16.eng: They’re kind, and live with their heart full of kindness.

mn114:8.17.pli: evarūpaṃ, bhante, cittuppādaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn114:8.17.eng: That arising of thought causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:8.18.eng: ‘I say that there are two arisings of thought:

mn114:8.19.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:8.20.eng: And each of these is an arising of thought.’

mn114:8.21.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn114:8.21.eng: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.

mn114:9.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two acquisitions of perception:

mn114:9.2.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:9.3.eng: And each of these is an acquisition of perception.’

mn114:9.5.eng: but why did he say it?

mn114:9.6.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, bhante, saññāpaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti evarūpo saññāpaṭilābho na sevitabbo;
mn114:9.6.eng: You should not cultivate the acquisition of perception which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:9.7.pli: yathārūpañca kho, bhante, saññāpaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti evarūpo saññāpaṭilābho sevitabbo.
mn114:9.7.eng: And you should cultivate the acquisition of perception which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:9.8.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, bhante, saññāpaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti?
mn114:9.8.eng: And what acquisition of perception causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline?

mn114:9.9.pli: Idha, bhante, ekacco abhijjhālu hoti, abhijjhāsahagatāya saññāya viharati;
mn114:9.9.eng: It’s when someone is covetous, and lives with their perception full of covetousness.

mn114:9.10.eng: They are malicious, and live with their perception full of ill will.

mn114:9.11.eng: They’re hurtful, and live with their perception intent on harm.

mn114:9.12.pli: evarūpaṃ, bhante, saññāpaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti.
mn114:9.12.eng: That acquisition of perception causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:9.13.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, bhante, saññāpaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti?
mn114:9.13.eng: And what acquisition of perception causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow?

mn114:9.14.pli: Idha, bhante, ekacco anabhijjhālu hoti, anabhijjhāsahagatāya saññāya viharati;
mn114:9.14.eng: It’s when someone is content, and lives with their perception full of contentment.

mn114:9.15.eng: They have good will, and live with their perception full of good will.

mn114:9.16.eng: They’re kind, and live with their perception full of kindness.

mn114:9.17.pli: evarūpaṃ, bhante, saññāpaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn114:9.17.eng: That acquisition of perception causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:9.18.eng: ‘I say that there are two acquisitions of perception:

mn114:9.19.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:9.20.eng: And each of these is an acquisition of perception.’

mn114:9.21.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn114:9.21.eng: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.

mn114:10.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two acquisitions of views:

mn114:10.2.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:10.3.eng: And each of these is an acquisition of views.’

mn114:10.5.eng: but why did he say it?

mn114:10.6.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, bhante, diṭṭhipaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti evarūpo diṭṭhipaṭilābho na sevitabbo;
mn114:10.6.eng: You should not cultivate the acquisition of views which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:10.7.pli: yathārūpañca kho, bhante, diṭṭhipaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti—evarūpo diṭṭhipaṭilābho sevitabbo.
mn114:10.7.eng: And you should cultivate the acquisition of views which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:10.8.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, bhante, diṭṭhipaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti?
mn114:10.8.eng: And what acquisition of views causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline?
mn114:10.8.comm: A view is a perception solidified into a persistent pattern of thought, which becomes a way of seeing the world. View offer explanatory power, provide us with a convenient template for understanding, and often dismissing, what we encounter. Once a view has set in, it tends to reinforce itself, and hence is very slow to change.

mn114:10.9.eng: It’s when someone has such a view:

mn114:10.10.pli: ‘natthi dinnaṃ, natthi yiṭṭhaṃ, natthi hutaṃ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, natthi ayaṃ loko, natthi paro loko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti—
mn114:10.10.eng: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’

mn114:10.11.pli: evarūpaṃ, bhante, diṭṭhipaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti.
mn114:10.11.eng: That acquisition of views causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:10.12.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, bhante, diṭṭhipaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti?
mn114:10.12.eng: And what acquisition of views causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow?

mn114:10.13.eng: It’s when someone has such a view:

mn114:10.14.pli: ‘atthi dinnaṃ, atthi yiṭṭhaṃ, atthi hutaṃ, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, atthi ayaṃ loko, atthi paro loko, atthi mātā, atthi pitā, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti—
mn114:10.14.eng: ‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There are such things as mother and father, and beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’

mn114:10.15.pli: evarūpaṃ, bhante, diṭṭhipaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn114:10.15.eng: That acquisition of views causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:10.16.eng: ‘I say that there are two acquisitions of views:

mn114:10.17.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:10.18.eng: And each of these is an acquisition of views.’

mn114:10.19.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn114:10.19.eng: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.

mn114:11.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of incarnation:

mn114:11.2.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:11.5.eng: but why did he say it?

mn114:11.6.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, bhante, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti—
mn114:11.6.eng: Incarnation that causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline:

mn114:11.7.eng: you should not cultivate such an incarnation.

mn114:11.8.pli: yathārūpañca kho, bhante, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti—
mn114:11.8.eng: Incarnation that causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow:

mn114:11.9.eng: you should cultivate such an incarnation.

mn114:11.10.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, bhante, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti?
mn114:11.10.eng: And what kind of incarnation causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline?
mn114:11.10.comm: As the examples will show, this refers to a kind of rebirth that is not conducive to developing wholesome qualities.

mn114:11.11.pli: Sabyābajjhaṃ, bhante, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṃ abhinibbattayato apariniṭṭhitabhāvāya akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;
mn114:11.11.eng: For one who generates a hurtful incarnation not for the sake of the state of perfection, unskillful qualities grow while skillful qualities decline.
mn114:11.11.comm: Apariniṭṭhitabhāvāya (“not for the sake of the state of perfection”) is found only here. The commentary explains it in terms of individuals who are reborn in a painful state where they are unable to realize the accomplishment of liberation.

mn114:11.12.pli: abyābajjhaṃ, bhante, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṃ abhinibbattayato pariniṭṭhitabhāvāya akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
mn114:11.12.eng: And what kind of incarnation causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow? For one who generates a pleasing incarnation for the sake of the state of perfection, unskillful qualities decline while skillful qualities grow.
mn114:11.12.comm: The question is absent in the Mahāsaṅgīti edition, but present in the PTS and BJT editions.

mn114:11.13.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of incarnation:

mn114:11.14.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:11.16.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn114:11.16.eng: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.

mn114:12.1.pli: Imassa kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa, vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa, evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
mn114:12.1.eng: Sir, that’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”
mn114:12.1.comm: This completes the elaboration of the seven items.

mn114:13.2.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, sāriputta, imassa mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa, vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa, evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsi.
mn114:13.2.eng: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of my brief statement in this way.”

mn114:14.1.eng: And the Buddha went on to repeat and endorse Venerable Sāriputta’s explanation in full. Then he went on to explain further:

mn114:14.6.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, sāriputta, kāyasamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti evarūpo kāyasamācāro na sevitabbo;

mn114:14.7.pli: yathārūpañca kho, sāriputta, kāyasamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti—

mn114:15.1.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, sāriputta, kāyasamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti?

mn114:15.2.pli: Idha, sāriputta, ekacco pāṇātipātī hoti luddo lohitapāṇi hatappahate niviṭṭho adayāpanno pāṇabhūtesu;

mn114:15.3.pli: adinnādāyī kho pana hoti, yaṃ taṃ parassa paravittūpakaraṇaṃ gāmagataṃ vā araññagataṃ vā taṃ adinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādātā hoti;

mn114:15.4.pli: kāmesumicchācārī kho pana hoti, yā tā māturakkhitā piturakkhitā mātāpiturakkhitā bhāturakkhitā bhaginirakkhitā ñātirakkhitā gottarakkhitā dhammarakkhitā sassāmikā saparidaṇḍā antamaso mālāguḷaparikkhittāpi tathārūpāsu cārittaṃ āpajjitā hoti—

mn114:15.5.pli: evarūpaṃ, sāriputta, kāyasamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti.

mn114:16.1.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, sāriputta, kāyasamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti?

mn114:16.2.pli: Idha, sāriputta, ekacco pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho, lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati;

mn114:16.3.pli: adinnādānaṃ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, yaṃ taṃ parassa paravittūpakaraṇaṃ gāmagataṃ vā araññagataṃ vā taṃ nādinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādātā hoti;

mn114:16.4.pli: kāmesumicchācāraṃ pahāya kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, yā tā māturakkhitā piturakkhitā mātāpiturakkhitā bhāturakkhitā bhaginirakkhitā ñātirakkhitā gottarakkhitā dhammarakkhitā sassāmikā saparidaṇḍā antamaso mālāguḷaparikkhittāpi tathārūpāsu na cārittaṃ āpajjitā hoti—

mn114:16.5.pli: evarūpaṃ, sāriputta, kāyasamācāraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.

mn114:16.9.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ mayā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.

mn114:20.6.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, sāriputta, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti evarūpo attabhāvapaṭilābho na sevitabbo;

mn114:20.7.pli: yathārūpañca kho, sāriputta, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti—

mn114:21.1.pli: Kathaṃrūpaṃ, sāriputta, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti?

mn114:21.2.pli: Sabyābajjhaṃ, sāriputta, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṃ abhinibbattayato apariniṭṭhitabhāvāya akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;

mn114:21.3.pli: abyābajjhaṃ, sāriputta, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṃ abhinibbattayato pariniṭṭhitabhāvāya akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.

mn114:21.7.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ mayā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.

mn114:21.8.pli: Imassa kho, sāriputta, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo.

mn114:22.1.eng: “I say that there are two kinds of sight known by the eye:
mn114:22.1.comm: Now the Buddha introduces the second analysis, in terms of the six senses.

mn114:22.2.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:22.3.eng: I say that there are two kinds of sound known by the ear …

mn114:22.5.eng: two kinds of smell known by the nose …

mn114:22.7.eng: two kinds of taste known by the tongue …

mn114:22.9.eng: two kinds of touch known by the body …

mn114:22.11.eng: two kinds of idea known by the mind:

mn114:22.12.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.”

mn114:23.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn114:23.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Sāriputta said to the Buddha:

mn114:23.2.pli: “imassa kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa, vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa, evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi.
mn114:23.2.eng: “Sir, this is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.
mn114:23.2.comm: Sāriputta proceeds to elaborate these six items in terms of what gives rise to the skillful and unskillful.

mn114:24.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of sight known by the eye:

mn114:24.2.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.’

mn114:24.4.eng: but why did he say it?

mn114:24.5.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, bhante, cakkhuviññeyyaṃ rūpaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti evarūpaṃ cakkhuviññeyyaṃ rūpaṃ na sevitabbaṃ;
mn114:24.5.eng: You should not cultivate the kind of sight known by the eye which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:24.6.pli: yathārūpañca kho, bhante, cakkhuviññeyyaṃ rūpaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti evarūpaṃ cakkhuviññeyyaṃ rūpaṃ sevitabbaṃ.
mn114:24.6.eng: And you should cultivate the kind of sight known by the eye which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:24.7.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of sight known by the eye:

mn114:24.8.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.’

mn114:24.9.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn114:24.9.eng: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.

mn114:25.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of sound known by the ear …

mn114:26.1.eng: two kinds of smell known by the nose …

mn114:27.1.eng: two kinds of taste known by the tongue …

mn114:27.3.eng: two kinds of touch known by the body …

mn114:29.1.eng: two kinds of idea known by the mind:

mn114:29.2.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.’

mn114:29.4.eng: but why did he say it?

mn114:30.1.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, bhante, manoviññeyyaṃ dhammaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti evarūpo manoviññeyyo dhammo na sevitabbo;
mn114:30.1.eng: You should not cultivate the kind of idea known by the mind which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:30.2.pli: yathārūpañca kho, bhante, manoviññeyyaṃ dhammaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti evarūpo manoviññeyyo dhammo sevitabbo.
mn114:30.2.eng: And you should cultivate the kind of idea known by the mind which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:30.3.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of idea known by the mind:

mn114:30.4.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.’

mn114:30.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn114:30.5.eng: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.

mn114:30.6.pli: Imassa kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa, vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa, evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
mn114:30.6.eng: Sir, that’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”

mn114:31.2.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, sāriputta, imassa mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa, vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa, evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsi.
mn114:31.2.eng: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of my brief statement in this way.”

mn114:32-36.1.eng: And the Buddha went on to repeat and endorse Venerable Sāriputta’s explanation in full. Then he went on to explain further:

mn114:32-36.5.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, sāriputta, cakkhuviññeyyaṃ rūpaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti evarūpaṃ cakkhuviññeyyaṃ rūpaṃ na sevitabbaṃ;

mn114:32-36.6.pli: yathārūpañca kho, sāriputta, cakkhuviññeyyaṃ rūpaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti evarūpaṃ cakkhuviññeyyaṃ rūpaṃ sevitabbaṃ.

mn114:32-36.9.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ mayā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.

mn114:38.6.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ mayā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.

mn114:38.7.pli: Imassa kho, sāriputta, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo.

mn114:39.1.eng: “I say that there are two kinds of robes:
mn114:39.1.comm: The Buddha introduces the third and final analysis, which shifts to the requisites and residence of a monastic.

mn114:39.2.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

mn114:39.3.eng: I say that there are two kinds of almsfood …

mn114:39.10.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.”

mn114:40.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn114:40.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Sāriputta said to the Buddha:

mn114:40.2.pli: “imassa kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa, vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa, evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi.
mn114:40.2.eng: “Sir, this is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.

mn114:41.1.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of robes …

mn114:41.5.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, bhante, cīvaraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti evarūpaṃ cīvaraṃ na sevitabbaṃ;

mn114:41.6.pli: yathārūpañca kho, bhante, cīvaraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti evarūpaṃ cīvaraṃ sevitabbaṃ.

mn114:41.9.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.

mn114:48.2.eng: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.’

mn114:48.4.eng: but why did he say it?

mn114:48.5.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, bhante, puggalaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti evarūpo puggalo na sevitabbo;
mn114:48.5.eng: You should not cultivate the kind of individual who causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

mn114:48.6.pli: yathārūpañca kho, bhante, puggalaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti evarūpo puggalo sevitabbo.
mn114:48.6.eng: And you should cultivate the kind of individual who causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

mn114:48.7.eng: ‘I say that there are two kinds of individual:

mn114:48.8.eng: those who you should cultivate, and those who you should not cultivate.’

mn114:48.9.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttanti.
mn114:48.9.eng: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.

mn114:49.1.pli: Imassa kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa, vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
mn114:49.1.eng: Sir, that’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”

mn114:50.2.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, sāriputta, imassa mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa, vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsi.
mn114:50.2.eng: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of my brief statement in this way.”

mn114:51-58.1.eng: And the Buddha went on to repeat and endorse Venerable Sāriputta’s explanation in full. Then he added:

mn114:51-58.5.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, sāriputta, cīvaraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti evarūpaṃ cīvaraṃ na sevitabbaṃ;

mn114:51-58.6.pli: yathārūpañca kho, sāriputta, cīvaraṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti evarūpaṃ cīvaraṃ sevitabbaṃ.

mn114:51-58.9.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ mayā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.

mn114:59.5.pli: Yathārūpaṃ, sāriputta, puggalaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti evarūpo puggalo na sevitabbo;

mn114:59.6.pli: yathārūpañca kho, sāriputta, puggalaṃ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti evarūpo puggalo sevitabbo.

mn114:59.9.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ mayā idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.

mn114:59.10.pli: Imassa kho, sāriputta, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo.

mn114:60.1.pli: Sabbepi ce, sāriputta, khattiyā imassa mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājāneyyuṃ, sabbesānampissa khattiyānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.
mn114:60.1.eng: “If all the aristocrats, brahmins, peasants, and menials were to understand the detailed meaning of my brief statement in this way, it would be for their lasting welfare and happiness.

mn114:60.4.pli: sabbepi ce, sāriputta, suddā imassa mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājāneyyuṃ, sabbesānampissa suddānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.

mn114:60.5.pli: Sadevakopi ce, sāriputta, loko samārako sabrahmako sassamaṇabrāhmaṇī pajā sadevamanussā imassa mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājāneyya, sadevakassapissa lokassa samārakassa sabrahmakassa sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
mn114:60.5.eng: If the whole world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—was to understand the detailed meaning of my brief statement in this way, it would be for the whole world’s lasting welfare and happiness.”

mn114:61.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn114:61.2.pli: Attamano āyasmā sāriputto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn114:61.2.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Sāriputta approved what the Buddha said.
